items.title: Antarctic meltwater alters future projections of climate and sea level
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 29 October 2025

Antarctic meltwater alters future projections of climate and sea level
                    Shaina Sadai 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6723-65311, Ambarish V. Karmalkar 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2940-04172, David Pollard 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2665-362X3, Yue Dong 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-6404-34464, Erica Lucas5, Natalya Gomez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2463-79175, Robert DeConto 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2800-64663 & …Alan Condron 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7337-17136 Show authors

Nature Communications

volume 16, Article number: 9271 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingCryospheric science

AbstractImperfect understanding of ice sheet-climate interactions poses challenges for projecting the impacts of ice sheet mass loss on future climate and sea level. Here we couple a dynamic Antarctic ice sheet model and global climate model to simulate ice sheet-climate interactions. In our single-model, single-member modeling framework, we find sea level and climate projections are significantly modified from uncoupled simulations neglecting Antarctic meltwater under RCP8.5 and RCP4.5. Antarctic meltwater yields surface air temperatures up to 1.5 °C higher in parts of the Northern Hemisphere, while broadly dampening temperature rise in the Southern Hemisphere. Due to radiative feedback changes, both emissions scenarios have global mean surface temperature warming ~0.3 °C lower in the coupled scenario than the control by 2100, with a maximum anomaly of ~1 °C at 2200 under RCP8.5. This slows Antarctica’s contribution to global mean sea level rise. Total Antarctic sea level contributions under RCP8.5 (2100: ~0.3 m, 2200: >3 m) include substantial contributions from East Antarctica, though not under RCP4.5 (2100: ~0.1 m, 2200: >1 m). Regionally, projected sea level is up to 0.9 m higher in the Pacific than the global mean Antarctic contribution under RCP8.5 at 2200.

IntroductionThe climate system is undergoing unprecedented changes as atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations continue to rise1. The resulting energy imbalance has accelerated ice sheet mass loss and sea level rise, which are projected to continue in coming centuries2. Current pledges submitted by parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change are insufficient for meeting the Paris Agreement’s Long-Term Temperature Goal of limiting global mean surface temperature (GMST) rise to “well below” 2 °C above pre-industrial values while “pursuing efforts” to limit it to 1.5 °C3. These pledges imply a 2.4-2.6 °C GMST rise by 2100, while current policies imply 2.7 °C warming4,5. Insufficient global mitigation risks are locking in large-scale ice sheet mass loss, exposing people and ecosystems around the world to substantial sea level rise. By 2060, over one billion people could be living in low elevation (<10 m above sea level) coastal areas, increasing the risks of sea level rise impacts for socially and geographically vulnerable populations6,7. Understanding interactions between ice sheets and the broader climate system will be key to constraining future Antarctic ice sheet (AIS) stability, global climate, and sea level8,9 which in turn has implications for global policy and climate justice10.Observations confirm that the AIS increasingly contributed to global mean sea level rise (GMSLR) in recent decades11, while model projections suggest that the AIS could become the dominant contributor to GMSLR in the coming centuries2. Incursions of Antarctic circumpolar deepwater in ice shelf cavities have been implicated as a cause of recent mass loss and grounding line retreat in sectors of East Antarctica12. Surface melt is currently observed to various extents across many ice shelves13 and is expected to become more frequent and longer lasting under medium to high emissions scenarios14. Additionally, continued atmospheric warming increases the potential for meltwater-driven hydrofracturing15, with ice shelves which provide substantial buttressing, being especially vulnerable16.As the AIS loses mass, meltwater and solid ice enter the Southern Ocean. The current generation of global climate models participating in phases 5 and 6 of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5 and CMIP6, respectively) lack interactive marine-based ice sheets capable of simulating dynamic ice sheet evolution, such as grounding line retreat, while iteratively coevolving with other climate model components17. As a result, CMIP5-6 simulations underestimate ice sheet melt responses under increasing greenhouse gas concentrations, and the impact of meltwater discharge on future climate and sea level17,18,19. In turn, meltwater-induced climate responses impact ice sheet evolution and consequently the timing and magnitude of future GMSLR. The locations of ice sheet mass loss determine the spatial distribution of sea level responses around the world, emphasizing the need to consider gravitational, rotational, and Earth deformation effects on sea level10,20,21 in addition to climate-ice sheet interactions.To assess climatic responses to greenhouse gas forcing and AIS discharge, prior modeling studies have conducted freshwater forcing experiments by adding meltwater to the Southern Ocean22,23,24,25,26. Despite variations in the location, quantity, and timing of freshwater input in these studies, modeled responses have several commonalities, including expanded Southern Ocean sea-ice, delayed GMST rise, increased ocean stratification, and subsurface ocean warming around the Antarctic margin. Warmer subsurface ocean temperatures and slowed atmospheric warming impact ice sheet evolution through increased basal melt and delayed surface melt, respectively. To better understand these interactions and more far-field impacts of Antarctic meltwater on the global climate system, dynamic ice sheets should be interactively embedded within global climate models27 and efforts to achieve this are advancing28. Recently, numerical experiments using coupling schemes under climate change projection scenarios have been used to assess climate-ice sheet feedbacks29,30 and a Southern Ocean meltwater forcing intercomparison project is underway17.Here, we present results from numerical simulations in which coupling is implemented between the Community Earth System Model (CESM) 1.2, a coupled global climate model which includes interactive atmosphere, ocean, land, and sea-ice modules31, and the Penn State University ice sheet model (PSU3D), a dynamic-thermodynamic ice sheet model32,33,34; (See Methods). We then use a global sea level model that includes 3D viscosity structure35,36 to understand the spatially variable sea level response resulting from Antarctic mass loss in our coupled ice sheet-climate simulations. Our coupling setup exchanges liquid and solid ice sheet discharge from PSU3D to coastal surface level grid cells in CESM, and passes 2 m air temperature, 400 m ocean temperature, and precipitation fields from CESM back to PSU3D. CESM does not simulate cavity circulation under floating ice shelves so bias-corrected ocean temperatures from CESM are extrapolated under ice shelves in PSU3D. Latent heat from solid ice discharge in PSU3D is accounted for in CESM. Latent heat from liquid melt is accounted for in PSU3D and therefore not reflected in modeled ocean temperatures in CESM. Ice sheet topography in CESM is fixed, while changes in topography evolve in PSU3D. As a result, changes in ice sheet surface height and extent simulated in PSU3D are not felt by the CESM atmosphere or land surface model. Temperature and precipitation values received by PSU3D are lapse rate corrected and surface melt is calculated with a positive degree day scheme, accounting for the partial refreezing of meltwater in the firn layer. Marine ice cliff instability (MICI) dynamics are included (See Methods), providing substantially more meltwater forcing than most previous climate-ice sheet studies. While the validity of MICI remains contested37, the intent here is to explore the global impact of meltwater forcing while including brittle ice dynamics which have informed high-end sea level projections.We explore changes in climate and sea level under future emissions scenarios RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 from 2005 to 2215. RCP scenarios were used rather than SSPs to make the best use of prior model simulations. RCP4.5 approximately corresponds to SSP2-4.5 and RCP8.5 to SSP5-8.538. While global mitigation efforts should preclude the RCP8.5 scenario in the long-term, we include this scenario because it tracks historical CO2 emissions39 and provides a useful case study for understanding coupled modeling responses. We include RCP4.5 as it results in end-of-century temperatures that are around or slightly above 2 °C40. Within the text, ‘coupled’ refers to the simulations with interactive coupling between the ice sheet model and climate model and ‘control’ (or ‘uncoupled’) refers to the simulations with no interactive AIS which are equivalent to a standard CESM1.2 simulation, which produces minimal meltwater41. Due to computational constraints, simulations have one ensemble member per emissions scenario. There is no interactive Greenland Ice Sheet in any simulations presented here as we focus on the Antarctic response. This work builds upon the one-way coupled modeling protocol of Sadai et al. (2020) by implementing interactive coupling.ResultsAntarctic contribution to global mean sea level riseIn agreement with modern observations (See Methods), we find that from 2005-2020 the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) contributes to a sea level rise while the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) displays a slight mass gain (Supplementary Fig. 1, Supplementary Table 1). Under RCP8.5, the EAIS begins consistently contributing to sea level rise by 2030, and by 2040 under RCP4.5. Under RCP8.5, the EAIS mass loss increases mainly due to ice shelf melting under a warming atmosphere, leading to an increase in iceberg calving and ice cliff failure at marine-terminating ice margins. As a result, the GMSLR contribution from the EAIS surpasses that from the WAIS by 2080 (Supplementary Table 1). By 2100, cumulative GMSLR contributions from West and East Antarctica are similar: 0.15 m from WAIS and 0.19 m from EAIS, producing a total contribution of 0.34 m (Fig. 1e, Supplementary Table 1). This is on the upper end of the 0.03–0.34 m range projected for Antarctica in IPCC AR6 under RCP8.52 and consistent with uncoupled climate-ocean-ice sheet simulations that also included ice cliff calving processes34. The WAIS contribution by 2100 is dominated by Thwaites Glacier retreating on reverse-sloped bedrock (i.e., from Marine Ice Sheet Instability, MISI, driven retreat) (Fig. 1c). Both Thwaites and Pine Island glaciers are mostly lost in the RCP8.5 simulation by the mid-22nd century. By 2200, both the Ross and Filchner-Ronne ice shelves collapse, the EAIS margin undergoes widespread mass loss, the Antarctic peninsula thins, and the WAIS retreats (Fig. 1d). Despite the onset of MISI in West Antarctica, the EAIS remains the dominant contributor to GMSLR through the end of the RCP8.5 simulation. The total GMSLR contribution from Antarctica by 2200 is 3.37 m, of which 1.75 m is sourced from the EAIS and 1.62 m from the WAIS (Fig. 1f, Supplementary Table 1).Fig. 1: Ice sheet response and Antarctic sea level rise contribution.a Change in Antarctic ice sheet thickness from 2005 to 2100 under RCP4.5. The ice sheet outline is the modeled grounding line position. b Same as a) but for 2200; c) Same as a) but for RCP8.5; d same as (b) but for RCP8.5. e Global mean sea level rise contributions from Antarctica, and mass loss in gigatons through 2100, for the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS), East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS), and total Antarctic contribution; f same as (e) through 2200. Maps created with Cartopy99.Full size imageUnder RCP4.5, lower greenhouse gas forcing limits the AIS GMSLR contribution to 0.13 m by 2100 with 0.1 m from WAIS and 0.03 m from EAIS (Fig. 1e, Supplementary Table 1). The pattern of ice loss mirrors that of RCP8.5 with Thwaites Glacier retreating and Ronne-Filchner thinning, but ice shelf thinning is less extensive overall, particularly in the EAIS (Fig. 1a). By 2200 the AIS GMSLR contribution reaches 1.17 m with 0.97 m from WAIS and 0.2 m from EAIS (Fig. 1f, Supplementary Table 1). The long-term view shows the impact of reducing greenhouse gas forcing; while WAIS still retreats substantially, large sections of the EAIS and portions of the Antarctic peninsula remain intact under RCP4.5 thereby limiting the AIS contribution to GMSLR.Polar climate responseAs CESM has static ice sheet topography, while PSU3D has evolving ice sheet topography, air temperatures noted here represent advected changes from evolving ocean conditions and do not reflect changes in the local land surface within CESM. In our coupled RCP8.5 experiment, surface air temperature (SAT) increases ~2–4 °C by 2100 across the Southern Ocean and AIS (Fig. 2a). Regionally, this is ~1–4 °C cooler than the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 2b). By the end of the 22nd century, there is widespread 5–10 °C warming across the ice sheet, especially in the Ross and Weddell Sea regions, although this is up to ~7 °C cooler than the uncoupled control simulation across the coastal region (Supplementary Fig. 2a, b). Under RCP4.5, SAT increases by ~1-2 °C by 2100 in the coupled simulation, except in the region of the Ross Sea where temperatures are lower by the end of 2100 and 2200 as compared to the start of the simulation (Supplementary Figs. 3a, 4a). Compared to the uncoupled simulation, SAT is ~1 °C cooler by 2100, although the coupled simulation is slightly warmer in a few locations (Supplementary Fig. 3b). By 2200 the cooler temperatures in the coupled simulation as compared to the control are more pronounced with the largest difference in the Ross Sea (Supplementary Fig. 4b).Fig. 2: Southern Ocean climate change by 2100 for RCP8.5.a Southern Ocean surface air temperature (SAT) change in the coupled simulation during the 21st century, b The SAT difference between the coupled and control simulations averaged over the last 30 years of the 21st century, c same as (a) but for precipitation, d same as (b) but for precipitation, e same as (a) but for 400 m ocean temperatures, f same as (b) but for 400 m ocean temperatures. Maps created with Cartopy99 with colormaps from100.Full size imageThroughout the RCP8.5 simulation, precipitation over the Southern Ocean increases (Fig. 2c; Supplementary Fig. 2c), although this change is less than in the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 2d; Supplementary Fig. 2d). The same overall patterns are found in RCP4.5 except the coupled simulation has slightly more precipitation than the control around Queen Maud and Wilkes Land by 2100 (Supplementary Fig. 3c, d). By 2200, precipitation in the coupled simulation has increased (Supplementary Fig. 4c) but is consistently lower in the RCP4.5 coupled simulation compared to the control (Supplementary Fig. 4d).By 2100, under RCP8.5, ocean temperatures at 400 m depth warm substantially across the Southern Ocean (Fig. 2e), driven by freshwater-induced stratification and reduced vertical mixing. The greatest warming is in the Weddell Sea, with a 3 °C temperature rise compared to the start of the simulation; the Ross Sea and EAIS margin near Wilkes Land warm by ~1 °C. The end of century difference between the coupled and control simulations (Fig. 2f), as compared to the warming over time in the coupled simulation (Fig. 2e), shows that much of the warming is due to meltwater forcing. By 2200, 400 m ocean temperatures show widespread ~2 °C warming relative to the start of the simulation (Supplementary Fig. 2e), with the Ross Sea ~4 °C warmer in the coupled simulation than the control (Supplementary Fig. 2f). Under RCP4.5, the Weddell Sea and region around Wilkes Land are 3 °C and 1 °C warmer, respectively, by 2100 (Supplementary Fig. 3e). As in RCP8.5, much of this warming is due to the impact of meltwater (Supplementary Fig. 3f). By 2200 in RCP4.5, warming intensifies with ~2 °C warming across the Southern Ocean since the start of the simulation (Supplementary Fig. 4e) and temperatures in the Ross and Weddell Seas up to 4 °C higher in the coupled simulation than the control (Supplementary Fig. 4f).The impacts of these climatic changes on the ice sheet explain the mass loss and contribution to GMSLR. Increases in SAT drive surface melt and induce hydrofracturing and ice shelf thinning while the accumulated ocean heat (i.e., warming at 400 m) increases basal melt under buttressing ice shelves. The concentration of heat in the Ross and Weddell Seas flips cold ice-shelf cavity circulation to warm cavity circulation patterns, accelerating loss of the large ice shelves, triggering MISI and in some places, ice cliff calving.Global climate responseOur coupled simulations show that the impacts of AIS discharge into the Southern Ocean are felt globally (Fig. 3). In both RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, freshwater forcing begins suppressing greenhouse gas induced GMST rise by the middle of the 21st century (Fig. 3c). Under RCP8.5, GMST is 0.33 °C lower by 2100 and 1.05°C lower by 2200 in the coupled simulation than in the control (Fig. 3d; Table 1). Under RCP4.5, GMST in the coupled simulation is 0.29°C lower by 2100 and 0.31°C lower by 2200 than in the control (Fig. 3d, Table 1). Compared to prior uncoupled experiments with the same models26, the impact of Antarctic meltwater on GMST is reduced due to the delayed ice sheet mass loss, and, therefore, lower meltwater input, that results from the interactive coupling.Fig. 3: Effect of Antarctic meltwater input on future climate.a The difference between the 2 m surface air temperature (SAT) in the RCP8.5 coupled experiment versus the control by the end of the century (2070-2099). b Same as (a) for RCP4.5. c Global mean surface temperature (GMST) above the 1850–1900 average with horizontal lines marking 1.5°, 2°, and 3 °C. d A time series of the temperature difference between the coupled and control simulations. e Difference in precipitation between the RCP8.5 coupled and control simulations at the end of the century. f Same as (e) for RCP4.5. g Zonal mean precipitation under the control simulations. h Same as (g) for the difference between the coupled and control simulations. Maps created with Cartopy99 with colormaps from101.Full size imageTable 1 Projected global mean sea level and air temperature riseFull size tableThe delayed GMST warming resulting from Southern Ocean freshwater forcing in our coupled simulations is caused by both a stronger ocean heat uptake efficiency (i.e., more efficient heat storage in the subsurface ocean) and a stronger atmospheric radiative feedback (i.e., more efficient radiative damping at the top of the atmosphere) (ref.42; See Methods). The former is owing to the increased ocean stratification and vertical heat redistribution in the Southern Ocean manifested as subsurface warming (Fig. 2f). The latter is due to the broad surface cooling in both the Southern Ocean and the tropical Pacific driven by freshwater forcing and large-scale teleconnections (Supplementary Fig. 6)42,43,44. The Southern Ocean cooling anomalies and sea-ice expansion locally enhance surface albedo feedback, whereas the tropical East Pacific surface cooling drives a more-stabilizing cloud feedback and lapse-rate feedback, resulting from the strengthened tropical west-east zonal sea surface temperature gradient45,46. The net radiative feedback parameter over the 21st century is therefore strengthened from −1.02 W/m²/K to −1.13 W/m²/K in the coupled RCP8.5 simulation, corresponding to a 0.4°C decrease in effective climate sensitivity (from 3.8°C to 3.4°C) relative to the uncoupled control simulation. The results are qualitatively consistent with the findings in our prior uncoupled freshwater forcing simulations26,42.Although GMST increases at a slower rate compared to our control simulations, the coupled simulations exhibit strong regional SAT variations (Fig. 3a, b). For example, by 2100 in RCP8.5, surface air temperatures over the Southern Ocean are ~1–1.5°C cooler, central and east Asia and the North Pacific are 0.3 °C warmer, and the North Atlantic, including Greenland, eastern North America and western Europe are 1-2°C warmer than in the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 3a). By 2200 in RCP8.5 (Supplementary Fig. 5a), anomalous cooling over the Southern Ocean continues, with temperatures >3°C cooler in the coupled experiment near the Antarctic continent. By 2100 under RCP4.5 the difference between the coupled and control experiments shows a bipolar temperature pattern with anomalous cooling in the Southern Hemisphere and anomalous warming in the Northern Hemisphere but the pattern differs from that seen in RCP8.5 with no strong warming over the North Atlantic and instead more diffuse warming across Asia, North Africa, and the Pacific Ocean (Fig. 3b). By 2200 in RCP4.5, anomalous cooling of ~1°C occurs over the Southern Ocean and Arctic with slight warming across much of the Northern Hemisphere and the most pronounced warming of ~0.5°C along the Pacific coast of North America (Supplementary Fig. 5c).The higher temperatures in the North Atlantic and North Pacific point to the existence of a bipolar seesaw, a pattern previously identified in Southern Ocean freshwater forcing experiments43,47,48. In RCP8.5, future slowing of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), defined as the maximum overturning at 24-26°N, is found to be largely delayed (Fig. 4a). In the coupled RCP8.5 simulation, the AMOC remains stronger than in the control from 2075 until the end of the simulation. The maximum difference between AMOC strength in the two simulations occurs at 2100 when the strongest signal of enhanced warming in both air (Fig. 3b) and sea surface temperatures (Supplementary Fig. 6) is observed in the coupled simulation. In RCP4.5, both the coupled and control simulations exhibit initial AMOC weakening followed by a partial recovery beginning after 2125. Under RCP4.5 whether the coupled or control simulation shows stronger AMOC strength is variable over time (Fig. 4a). In addition, northward heat transport is found to decrease under both RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 forcing (Fig. 4b). The largest differences occur at low-to-mid northern latitudes where the Atlantic Ocean is most effective at transporting heat northward.Fig. 4: Change in overturning circulation strength and northward heat transport due to coupling.a Meridional overturning circulation (MOC) strength in the Atlantic Ocean for the coupled and control simulations under RCP8.5 and RCP4.5, b northward heat transport in the Atlantic Ocean averaged over the period 2070-2099.Full size imageCoupled meltwater simulations under both RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 show a robust northward shift of the intertropical convergence zone, due to zonal-mean energetic constraints associated with the anomalous inter-hemispheric surface temperature gradient49. In the Southern Hemisphere, wide-spread surface cooling is accompanied with broad drying while in the Northern Hemisphere, precipitation generally increases (Fig. 3 and Supplementary Fig. 5), which may arise from both local temperature changes or remote tropical teleconnections50. Under RCP8.5, zonal mean precipitation in the control simulation changes little over time (Fig. 3g) while in the coupled simulation it enhances north of the equator and diminishes to the south (Fig. 3h).Broader Implications of Antarctic Ice LossAntarctic mass loss has important implications for people around the world. Fully understanding the potential impact of Antarctica’s contribution to sea level necessitates analyzing the spatial pattern of the sea level response. Global sea level change patterns from ice sheet mass loss are spatially variable due to gravitational, rotational, and Earth deformational (GRD) effects51. Using a 3D viscoelastic Earth structure model (See Methods) which includes anomalously low viscosities under the WAIS allows us to account for the sea level impact of water expulsion into the open ocean from formerly ice-covered areas undergoing uplift due to glacial isostatic adjustment52. Patterns of sea level change from GRD effects vary spatially and temporally depending on the regions of Antarctic mass loss21,51. Consistent with prior research10,21 we find that regions northward of 30°S will experience sea level rise higher than the Antarctic contribution to GMSLR regardless of emissions scenario and timescales. However, the most heavily impacted regions vary (Fig. 5). Under RCP4.5 by 2100 the Indian, Pacific, and Atlantic Ocean basins, including the Caribbean, experience 0.03 m higher regional sea level rise than the global mean (Fig. 5a). By 2200 the pattern is similar but the difference between the highest impacted regions increases by an order of magnitude to 0.3 m (Fig. 5c). Under RCP8.5 by 2100, most of the Pacific basin is projected to experience regional sea level rise of up to 0.09 m higher than the GMSLR of 0.34 m (Fig. 5b). This pattern remains at 2200 with areas in the central Pacific experiencing 0.9 m more regional sea level rise than the GMSLR of 3.37 m while the Indian and Atlantic Ocean basins experience 0.6 and 0.7 m higher regional sea levels, respectively (Fig. 5d). These regional changes are solely based on the Antarctic response but realized sea level would also depend on Greenland mass loss, thermosteric responses, and other factors which are not accounted for here21,53.Fig. 5: Spatial change in sea level resulting from projected Antarctic ice sheet mass loss.a The spatial pattern of sea level change resulting from gravitational, rotational, and Earth deformational effects at 2100 under RCP4.5. The purple band designates the global mean sea level contribution from the Antarctic ice sheet. b same as (a) for RCP8.5. c same as (a) for 2200. d same as (b) for 2200. Maps created with ArcGIS using Natural Earth land boundaries.Full size imageContrasting the global sea level response to the influence of meltwater on GMST has implications for global mitigation efforts and climate (in)justice10. Under RCP8.5, the timing when GMST exceeds 1.5–2°C above preindustrial (defined here following IPCC AR6 as when the 20-year rolling mean exceeds 1.5–2°C above the 1850–1900 average) is minimally affected by the meltwater induced delay in GMST rise (Supplementary Fig. 7a). This is because these warming values are surpassed before the meltwater-induced delayed warming effect strengthens. In our simulations, under high emissions (RCP8.5) 1.5°C is passed by 2026 and 2°C is delayed by 1 year in the coupled simulation. Under RCP4.5, 1.5°C and 2°C are each delayed by 1 year in the coupled simulation (Supplementary Fig. 7b). Given that these are single model runs with one set of models, how meltwater effects and other climate feedbacks impact the timing of different temperature thresholds remains deeply uncertain.While the timing of the Long-Term Temperature Goal is minimally impacted, the long-term difference in GMST when accounting for meltwater input and feedbacks is substantial (Table 1) and relevant for informing future global mitigation target setting. The strength of the delayed GMST warming that occurs from Antarctic meltwater forcing should be considered alongside other climate feedbacks, such as the anticipated enhanced warming effect of permafrost melt. The combined impacts of climatic changes that influence GMST with other impacts such as sea level rise could pose substantial challenges if a GMST-based metric was used to inform international policy post-210010. In this study we find that GMST is 1.05 °C lower under RCP8.5 by 2200 in the coupled simulation compared to the control, but this relatively cooler climate trajectory is commensurate with an Antarctic GMSLR contribution of 3.37 m and regional sea level rise of up to 4.3 m in the Pacific (Fig. 5d). Under RCP4.5, GMST is 0.31°C lower in the coupled simulation by 2200 while Antarctica’s contribution to GMSLR is 1.17 m and regional sea level rise of up to 1.5 m occurs in the Pacific and Indian Ocean basins and Caribbean Sea (Fig. 5c). In other words, while the loss of ice sheet mass results in a slightly lower GMST rise in the coupled simulations, it drives substantial sea level rise. This supports previous work which has argued that focusing on GMST as a metric to inform climate action could exacerbate climate justice concerns10. Even with a slower rate of warming, any continued increase in sea level poses risks to island and coastal communities, and raises wide-ranging issues of intergenerational inequity and distributive injustice10. The implications for justice and policy are complex and influenced by many other factors that require further detailed study.DiscussionHere we have modeled the impacts of Antarctic ice sheet discharge on climate and sea level using an ice sheet model and climate model in interactive coupling, combined with sea level fingerprint modeling to understand the global patterns of sea level change resulting from ice sheet mass loss. We find that projected rates of future GMST rise are reduced in our coupled simulations under RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 compared to uncoupled simulations. The patterns of meltwater-induced climate effects are not uniform, with reduced future warming over the Southern Ocean and enhanced warming in RCP8.5 over large parts of the Northern Hemisphere, especially by 2100.We project a global mean Antarctic contribution to sea level rise of 0.34 m by 2100 and 3.37 m by 2200 under RCP8.5, with 0.13 m by 2100 and 1.17 m by 2200 under RCP4.5 (Table 1). Patterns of sea level change are not spatially uniform and more heavily impacted locations vary based on the pattern of ice sheet mass loss. We find that the EAIS contribution to GMSLR over multi-century timescales rivals that of the WAIS and is even slightly higher than that from the WAIS under RCP8.5. Paleoclimate evidence shows signs of past ice sheet retreat in deep EAIS subglacial basins, while future model projections show differing responses. A recent review54 concluded that the EAIS has the potential to contribute substantially to GMSLR, particularly on multi-century timescales and under high emissions scenarios, as we find here. This also has implications for interpreting sources of sea level rise in the geologic past, which should not assume that the EAIS can only provide a substantial contribution after WAIS has lost all marine-based ice.Arctic temperatures are higher in the RCP8.5 coupled simulation than in the control before 2050 and for a multi-decade period centered around 2100. While this study is based on understanding the impact of a coupled AIS, this SAT response could drive enhanced ice loss on Greenland which could have significant impacts on subpolar North Atlantic deepwater formation and AMOC strength55. An important next step will be the addition of an interactively coupled Greenland ice sheet model.There is a wide spread of projections for the Antarctic contribution to sea level across models. ISMIP6 compared projections across 10 ice sheet models using standardized CMIP5 ocean and atmospheric forcing under RCP8.5 and RCP2.6. They find responses ranging from a sea level fall of 0.078 to a sea level rise of 0.3 m for RCP8.5 by 210056. The range of projected GMSLR contributions from the AIS as assessed in IPCC AR6 under SSP2-4.5 is 0.03-0.29 m at 2100 and -0.05-0.55 m at 21502,57. Our projected values under RCP4.5 of 0.13 m at 2100 and 0.55 m at 2150 (Table 1, Supplementary Table 1) are at the mid-range and upper end at each time period, respectively. For SSP5-8.5 the IPCC AR6 assessed range is 0.03–0.34 m at 2100 and -0.11–0.66 m at 2150 without deeply uncertain ice sheet processes like ice cliff collapse included, or 0.02–0.56 at 2100 and -0.11–3.68 when including uncertain ice sheet processes2,57. Our projected values under RCP8.5 of 0.34 m at 2100 and 1.45 m at 2150 place our results by 2100 at the upper end when comparing to a range that excludes uncertain ice sheet processes or in the middle of the range that includes uncertain processes while our values at 2150 are higher than the range that excludes uncertain processes and in the middle of the range that includes them. While these values are plausible and in line with the scientific consensus we note that this study is only using a single model and thus should be taken as one possibility of how future projections may evolve.Our study is one of several that have coupled ice sheet models to climate models. Park et al.29 interactively coupled the same dynamic ice sheet model used in our study (PSU3D) to an intermediate complexity climate model (LOVECLIM), finding that freshwater-induced suppression of atmospheric warming reduced Antarctic mass loss and GMSLR contributions through 2150, in line with our findings using a coupled general circulation model. Siahaan et al.30 used a different set of coupled models (BISICLES and UKESM) and found Antarctica contributed to a sea level fall by the end of their simulation period in 2100 under RCP8.5 due to increased snowfall exceeding mass loss. The study presented here differs from previous studies by providing a longer term simulation to 2200, including a radiative feedback analysis which allows for an assessment of the mechanisms behind delayed GMST rise, and offline coupling to a sea level model which allows for an assessment of the global sea level fingerprint that results from AIS mass loss. By including an ice sheet model that simulates hydrofracturing and ice-cliff calving, ice loss in our simulations is highly sensitive to evolving atmospheric conditions. This also tests the climate impacts and feedbacks resulting from a large meltwater flux to the Southern Ocean. More generally, our study complements previous work by assessing divergent climate-sea level responses of different sets of coupled models, highlighting the need to include dynamic ice sheets in more global climate models.The results presented here demonstrate the importance of embedding dynamic ice sheet models within Earth system models used for future climate, ice sheet, and sea level projections. They also highlight the global risks of Antarctic ice sheet instability under rising greenhouse gas emissions, underscoring the need to reduce emissions in the immediate near-term.MethodsModel descriptions and initializationThe climate model used is Community Earth System Model 1.2.2 with Community Atmospheric Model 5 atmospheric physics (CESM1-CAM5)31. CESM1.2 is a coupled global Earth system model containing interactive ocean, atmosphere, sea-ice, and land models linked via a coupler. The continent and ocean boundaries do not change in CESM1.2. CESM1.2 does not include fully interactive Greenland or Antarctic ice sheets58. It was run with 1° resolution for the ocean and sea-ice components and 0.9×1.25° resolution for the atmosphere and land components. The model grid has a displaced pole over Greenland. It is initialized with 20th century restart files. Simulations spanning the period from 2005-2200 and were conducted under Representative Concentration Pathway RCP8.5 and RCP4.559.The Antarctic ice sheet model used is the Penn State University ice sheet model (PSU3D)32,33. PSU3D is a three-dimensional ice sheet model that approximates ice flow using hybrid ice dynamics with an imposed parameterization of ice flux across the grounding line60, allowing for realistic simulation of grounding line retreat32. In these simulations it is run at a 10 km resolution with basal sliding coefficients obtained from an inverse run matching modeled surface elevations and observations61. Initial conditions were from DeConto et al.34, which included simulations using offline CESM1.2 forcing. Bed topographic boundary conditions use Bedmap262. We use CESM1.2 and PSU3D with Bedmap2 boundary conditions to make the best use of previously run control experiments.Models were run on the NCAR Cheyenne high performance computing system63. For the control scenarios, there is no freshwater forcing provided by the PSU3D ice sheet model. Testing determined that our RCP8.5 control matched the SAT evolution of the standard CMIP5 CESM1 simulation for RCP8.5, which is used for the time series in Fig. 364. For RCP4.5, data from CESM1-CAM5_rcp45_r1i1p1 obtained from the CMIP5 data repository was used as a control65. Preindustrial temperature data was obtained from the CMIP5 data repository66.Coupling methodologyCESM1.2 and PSU3D are run with an annual interactive coupling scheme allowing for a dynamic response of the ice sheet to changes in the climate model, and response of the climate system to ice sheet freshwater discharge. The annual coupling is accomplished as follows67. An initial climatology is used to force PSU3D for one model year (2005), provided from a standard CESM1.2 control simulation lacking additional meltwater forcing. The ice sheet model is then run for one model year to provide liquid water and solid ice discharge from the ice sheet, interpolated onto the CESM1.2 ocean grid at the nearest coastal ocean cell from where the mass loss occurs in the ice sheet. Latent heat is accounted for as solid ice melts. The ice sheet model internally determines which types of ice sheet discharge exit as a solid or liquid. Latent heat of the solid ice discharge phase change is accounted for in the climate model while latent heat for liquid fields is accounted for within the ice sheet model32. Latent heat from fields the ice sheet counts as liquid is accounted for within the ice sheet model. This may underestimate the delayed warming effect of ice sheet discharge on global climate; therefore, the extent of the delayed warming effect seen in this study should be taken as a lower bound. The fields the ice sheet model outputs as liquid melt components include ice sheet basal melt, sub-ocean ice face melt, percolation of meltwater to the base, and the counter effect of basal refreezing while the solid ice discharge forcing contains ice lost from calving and cliff failure. Liquid and solid discharge components enter the climate model at the surface ocean level55,68. While injecting freshwater at depth can lead to more mixing and a deeper mixed layer and work with other ocean models has shown the depth of freshwater input to have an effect in other models69, previous work with CESM indicates that there is little difference in CESM1-simulated ocean surface temperature, salinity, and sea-ice responses when freshwater is applied at depth versus in experiments where freshwater is added at the surface41. Following the calculation of interpolated liquid and solid ice sheet discharge, CESM1.2 is then run for one model year to obtain a meltwater-perturbed climatology. Ocean temperature at 400 m depth, 2 m surface air temperatures, and precipitation are then passed back to the ice sheet. The ice sheet model is built to intake ocean temperatures at 400 m as this depth level is representative of where warm deep water enters the Amundsen Sea Embayment70,71.Initial surface topography is provided to the climate sheet model by the ice sheet model at the first time step. At subsequent time steps, deviations between the input topography and evolving ice sheet topography are accommodated via lapse rate corrections for temperature and precipitation70. The fraction of input precipitation that falls as snow versus rain is parameterized based on the input surface air temperature. The ice sheet model surface mass balance calculations account for surface melting and refreezing as well as percolation of liquid water below the ice sheet surface layer. Surface melt is calculated via a positive degree day scheme, which calculates melt from the input temperature and precipitation, with melt beginning at -1°C based on observational relationships72.Ocean forcing of the ice sheetThe ocean melt rate parameterization is a quadratic function of the temperature difference between the nearest ocean grid cell and the depth-dependent freezing temperature which is defined as follows.$${{\rm{Ocean}}}\_{{\rm{melt}}}=({{K}} \; {{\rm{K}}}_{T\rho w}{{{\rm{C}}}}_{{{\rm{W}}}})/({L}_{f}\rho i)|{T}_{o}\,{{\rm{\hbox{-}}}}\,{T}_{f}|({T}_{o}\,{{\rm{\hbox{-}}}}\,{T}_{f})$$
                    (1)
                Where To is input 400 m ocean temperature, Tf is the freezing-point temperature at the base of the ice at a given depth, ρw and ρi are the densities of water and ice, cW is the specific heat of ocean water, Lf is the latent heat of fusion, KT is a transfer factor, and K is a set of tunable parameters32.This parameterization has been shown to be one of the best performing options for representing both integrated shelf melt and grounding line melt73. Melting at submerged vertical ice faces is calculated from the ocean melt rate of surrounding grid cells and increased by a scaling factor of 2 to better match observations. This scaling factor is lower than the scaling factor of 10 which was used in previous uncoupled ice sheet simulations34,70.To bring the ocean temperatures being passed to the ice sheet into closer agreement with observational values, the ocean temperature at 400 m is bias corrected using World Ocean Atlas 2018 observational temperatures74,75. As CESM1.2 does not have ocean cavities under ice shelves, ocean temperatures are taken from the static edge of the continent using a grid-cell-by-grid-cell stepping approach to determine the ocean temperature at the ice shelf edge wherever it is available in the ocean model. The ice sheet model interpolates them to the ice sheet grid and linearly extrapolates a value back into the interior of the shelf. To avoid a small number of warm grid cells from having an oversized impact on melt rates when interpolated over a large shelf, a single value is calculated as the average of all ocean grid cells in polygons specifying each ice shelf’s area and that one value is interpolated under that shelf. To bring melt rates in the Amundsen Sea region into closer alignment with observational values, a 2.5°C anomaly is added in that region, similar to the bias corrections applied in previous work with PSU3D34,70.Calving sensitivity and cliff failureAs in previous work with PSU3D, surface crevasse depth is influenced by surface melt and rainwater, assuming a quadratic relationship between meltwater production (R) and crevasse penetration depth (dw).$${d}_{w}={{\rm{CALVLIQ}}}{R}^{2}$$
                    (2)
                This meltwater enhanced crevassing (dw) influences ice shelf hydrofracturing and calving33,34. To bring mass loss from calving in line with observations over the modern period the CALVLIQ parameter is set to 35 m-1yr2.As used here, the ice sheet model accounts for enhanced calving at thick (O 1000 m) marine-terminating ice fronts that have lost their buttressing ice shelves, leaving tall subaerial ice cliffs prone to brittle failure76. Ice cliff calving occurs at calving fronts where the stresses exceed the yield strength. The cliff calving parameterization is applied as a horizontal wastage with a maximum rate of 7.7e3 m/y34. We note that the role of marine ice cliff calving in future Antarctic ice loss remains contested37,77, with much of the uncertainty caused by a lack of observations and poorly constrained physical properties of damaged glacial ice78,79.Model validationBefore the coupled run was integrated, several shorter tests were done under transient climate forcing from 2005-2020 to check for consistency between model results and existing observational measurements. The total modeled rate of basal melt around the continent from 2005-2017 is 1343.21 Gt/yr67, in alignment with rates from80 [1280-1628 Gt/yr] and81 [1010-1310 Gt/yr]. The total modeled calving rate over this period is 974.874 Gt/yr67, slightly below the estimate of 1177-1465 Gt/yr in ref. 80. The modeled basal melt rates at the Pine Island, Thwaites, Ross, and Ronne-Filchner ice shelves are 36.4, 35.1, 0.28, and 0.27 m/yr, respectively67 as compared to81 [14, 26.7, 0.3, 0.2 m/yr] and82 [16.2, 17.2, 0.3, 0.3 m/yr]. While modeled rates of ice loss are higher than the average observed melt rates at PIG and Thwaites, the total sea level rise contribution from the WAIS is in line with observations and areas of higher melt rates (up to 43 m/yr) have been seen at the Thwaites grounding line83. From 2005 to 2017, the total modeled AIS sea level rise contribution is 2 mm, lower than the 7.4 ± 1.5 mm Antarctic contribution reported for 1992–202011 implying that the coupled simulation is slightly underestimating sea level rise contributions during this observational period. The spatial patterns of changes in ice thickness from 2005 to 2020 compare well with observations from84 (their Fig. 1 compared to our Supplementary Fig. 1).Sea level rise calculationsGlobal mean sea level contributions are calculated using the modified volume above flotation (VAF) method which accounts for the rise or fall of bedrock elevation below grounded ice which changes VAF but does not alter sea level85.Geographically variable sea level changes accounting for gravitational, Earth rotational86 and Maxwell viscoelastic deformational87 effects are calculated by solving the sea level equation51,88. Calculations account for migrating shorelines and inundation of areas freed of marine grounded ice88,89. We adopt the finite volume sea level solver to solve the sea level equation on a global tetrahedral grid including 3D variations in Earth’s rheological structure35. We adopt the 3D viscosity structure and laterally varying lithospheric thickness model EM3D_L90 based on ANT-20 regional seismic tomography model91 in Antarctica and S362ANI global seismic tomography model92 across the rest of the globe. Lithosphere thickness in the model is based on93 over Antarctica and a global model94 elsewhere. Globally, the adopted computational grid has an average spatial (lateral and radial) resolution of 12 km from the surface to the Mohorovičić Discontinuity (MOHO), 25 km to 220 km depth, and 50 km to the core mantle boundary. The grid is regionally refined in Antarctica, with a resolution of 6 km to the base of the MOHO, 12 km to 220 km depth, and 25 km to 350 km depth36. The ice sheet model provides the initial topography in Antarctica, and this is merged with ETOPO2 elsewhere.Global energy budget analysisThe ocean heat uptake efficiency parameter (κ) and the radiative feedback parameter (λ) are calculated as:$$\kappa={dN}/{dT},\lambda=d(N-F)/{dT},$$
                    (3)
                Where dN is the global-mean net top of atmosphere radiation imbalance, dF is effective radiative forcing and dT is the global-mean near-surface air temperature change42. Based on the global-mean energy budget framework95,96, the transient global warming rate (dT/dt) can be approximated as:$${dT}/{dt}=({dF}/{dt})/(\kappa -\lambda )$$
                    (4)
                Where we substitute values of κ or λ from control or coupled simulations to isolate the impacts of ocean heat uptake efficiency or radiative feedback on the global warming rate42. Effective climate sensitivity is calculated as:$${{\rm{EffCS}}}=-{F}_{2x}/\lambda$$
                    (5)
                Where F2x represents the effective radiative forcing from a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The value of F2x in CESM1.2 is 3.88 Wm2 97. EffCS is an analog to equilibrium climate sensitivity except using λ from a transient state assuming λ remains constant until equilibrium42.Data visualizationSpatial sea level maps were created in ArcGIS using a Goode homolosine ocean-oriented projection10,98. Figures 1–3 and supplemental figures were created with Cartopy99. Sea level maps use country outlines provided by Natural Earth shapefiles: Pacific groupings, 1:10 m countries, 1:50 m Tiny Country Points. On some figures scientific colormaps are from100,101.

Data availability
              
              The climate data and spatial sea level mapping data generated in this study and referenced in the paper have been deposited in the University of Massachusetts Amherst ScholarWorks repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56)102. The climate model data fields and spatial sea level data not referenced in this paper are available for non-commercial use from the corresponding authors due to difficulties hosting a large dataset externally. The ice sheet model data is available in the ScholarWorks repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56)102. Data for the 1850-1900 baseline and CMIP5 RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 simulations are available from the Centre for Environmental Data Analysis64,65,66. Natural Earth country boundary data is available at www.naturalearthdata.com.
            Code availability
              
              CESM1.2 is available from the National Center for Atmospheric Research. The PSU3D code is available in the ScholarWorks repository102, please contact DP and RD for assistance running it. The 3D GIA model is available from the code’s developer Konstantin Latychev. Scripts for running the models and creating the figures are in the data repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56).

items.title: FER 2 | PUBBLICATE LE GRADUATORIE DEL SECONDO BANDO
items.description: Il GSE ha pubblicato le graduatorie della seconda procedura competitiva per gli impianti a biogas, ai sensi del DM FER2. Riportiamo di seguito gli ult
items.body:
FER 2 | PUBBLICATE LE GRADUATORIE DEL SECONDO BANDO

28 Ottobre 2025

Il GSE ha pubblicato le graduatorie della seconda procedura competitiva per gli impianti a biogas, ai sensi del DM FER2.Riportiamo di seguito gli ulteriori dettagli contenuti nella comunicazione del GSE:Nella pagina Rinnovabili elettriche>accesso agli incentivi>Graduatorie FER2 sono consultabili:la graduatoria degli impianti risultati in posizione utile (Tabella A);gli elenchi degli impianti esclusi (Tabella B).Le richieste di accesso agli incentivi per gli impianti ammessi in Tabella A devono essere presentate tramite il Portale FER-E entro 30 giorni solari dalla data di entrata in esercizio, nei tempi previsti dal DM FER2 e dalle Regole Operative, pena l’applicazione del c.d. “fuori tempo“.Ai soggetti proponenti degli impianti esclusi in fase di formazione delle graduatorie, il GSE invierà una comunicazione specificando i motivi dell’esclusione.Per ulteriori informazioni è possibile consultare la sezione Rinnovabili elettriche / FER 2.						
				
				
				
					
			
						
									Consulta la graduatoria FER 2
					
					
		
				
				
				
				
					
			
						
									Leggi la news sul sito del GSE

items.title: Ge Vernova: indicazioni geografiche ed operative per evento di Green Team Building a Lucera (FG)
items.description: Gentilissimi Partecipanti all‘evento di team building, questa pagina è pensata per fornirvi tutti i dettagli tecnici sull’attività che and
items.body:
Ge Vernova: indicazioni geografiche ed operative per evento di Green Team Building a Lucera (FG)

27.10.2025

condividi:

Gentilissimi Partecipanti all'evento di team building, questa pagina è pensata per fornirvi tutti i dettagli tecnici sull'attività che andremo a realizzare. Le attività di Team Building, promosse da Rete Clima, sono progettate per favorire la crescita delle foreste italiane e della biodiversità. Un modo concreto per dimostrare l’impegno verso la responsabilità ambientale, dando corpo alle strategie aziendali ESG.

In aggiunta a quanto specificato di seguito, per qualunque necessità o approfondimento ci possiamo sentire tramite email o telefono (contatti in fondo alla pagina).

Indicazioni generali

Quando: 2 dicembre 2025 - con data di backup in caso di mal tempo fissata per il giorno 16 dicembre (stesso orario).

Dove: ritrovo alle ore 10:30 presso l'area adiacente alla Masseria Sant'Agapito - A Rural Odyssey, dove vi accoglierà il personale di Rete Clima: vedi Link Google Maps

Iscrizione all'evento: clicca qui per iscriverti

Programma

saluti e introduzione alle attività forestali: illustrazione delle corrette tecniche forestali per la piantagione degli alberi, distribuzione DPI (guanti da lavoro) e dei materiali di lavoro;

Avvio delle attività;

Conclusione dei lavori, chiusura dell'evento e saluti.

Raccomandazioni

Abbigliamento: comodo/sportivo, con scarpe robuste o sportive, meglio se da trekking. Utile preparare un "abbigliamento aziendale", con magliette, cappellini, grembiuli e altri capi personalizzati con il logo aziendale.

Campagna nazionale Foresta Italia: SDGs raggiunti e Patrocini

Di seguito i riferimenti relativi alle attività forestali che svolgeremo insieme:

L'attività è svolta nell'ambito della nostra Campagna forestale nazionale Foresta Italia®.

Contatti Team Rete Clima:

Diego Scaglia: 339 4995893 - diego.scaglia@reteclima.it

items.title: Plastic Overshoot day: la plastica supera i limiti di sua corretta gestione
items.description: Che cos’è il Plastic Overshoot Day? Rappresenta la teorica data in cui la quantità di rifiuti di plastica prodotti a livello globale supera la c
items.body:
Plastic Overshoot day: la plastica supera i limiti di sua corretta gestione

24.10.2025 -                                 News

condividi:

Che cos'è il Plastic Overshoot Day?

Rappresenta la teorica data in cui la quantità di rifiuti di plastica prodotti a livello globale supera la capacità di gestirli in maniera sicura, con conseguente concreto rischio di inquinamento ambientale.

A livello globale si parla di 72,1 milioni di tonnellate di rifiuti di plastica che non saranno gestiti correttamente con il serio rischio di disperdersi e di degradarsi nell’ambiente.

Una cifra drammatica che mette in luce quanto la crisi legata al ciclo di vita della plastica non sia più solo un problema ambientale ed un problema climatico, come già discusso in questo nostro articolo, ma sia anche una questione di salute pubblica.

Il Wwf Italia ha colto l’occasione per richiamare l’attenzione sulle conseguenze della plastica nella vita quotidiana e nel corpo umano.

Studi recenti hanno evidenziato la presenza di microplastiche in quasi tutti gli organi, dal cervello al sangue, fino alla placenta, sollevando interrogativi sui possibili effetti neurologici e riproduttivi.

L’allarme non è solo per gli ecosistemi: la plastica, ormai ubiqua, tocca direttamente la nostra salute.

Ogni Stato ha il proprio Plastic Overshoot Day.

In Italia la data è fissata al 24 ottobre, in anticipo rispetto a Germania e Spagna, ma molto più presto rispetto a paesi come Singapore e Corea del Sud, dove la gestione dei rifiuti plastici risulta più efficiente.

Fonte: pexels.com

Questo confronto ha spinto a riflettere sull’importanza di un cambiamento sistemico: governi, imprese e cittadini dovevano collaborare per ridurre la plastica, migliorare le infrastrutture di gestione e adottare soluzioni circolari.

Il WWF ha invitato a politiche concrete: estendere la raccolta differenziata a tutti i settori produttivi, introdurre una tassa sulla plastica vergine, incentivare il riuso e potenziare le infrastrutture di raccolta e gestione dei rifiuti di plastica.

Allo stesso tempo ha rilanciato la filosofia delle 4R – Riduci, Riutilizza, Ricicla, Recupera – come pratica quotidiana accessibile a tutti.

Il Plastic Overshoot Day rappresenta più di una semplice data simbolica.

È stato uno specchio della nostra società e dei nostri comportamenti, è un invito a riflettere su come ogni scelta individuale possa contribuire a un cambiamento collettivo: ogni scelta quotidiana, dai comportamenti individuali alle decisioni politiche, può contribuire a invertire la rotta.

Fonte: pexels.com

La lezione è chiara: il Plastic Overshoot Day non è allora davvero solo una data simbolica, ma un richiamo concreto a ripensare il nostro rapporto con la plastica.

Agire oggi significa proteggere l’ambiente e la nostra salute, prima che il prossimo limite venga superato.

Programma

saluti e introduzione alle attività forestali;

sopralluogo alle aree schiantate e illustrazione di cause ed effetti della tempesta di vento che ha provocato gli schianti forestali;

spiegazione delle corrette tecniche forestali per la piantagione degli alberi, distribuzione DPI (guanti da lavoro) e dei materiali di lavoro;

attività di forestazione simbolica;

consegna delle etichette aziendali da posizionare sugli alberi;

conclusione dei lavori, chiusura dell'evento e saluti.

Raccomandazioni

Abbigliamento: comodo/sportivo, con scarpe robuste o sportive, meglio se da trekking. Utile preparare un "abbigliamento aziendale", con magliette, cappellini, grembiuli e altri capi personalizzati con il logo aziendale.

Informazioni sull'area

Fonte immagine: https://www.italia.it/it/lombardia/parco-lombardo-della-valle-del-ticino

L’intervento riguarda il ripristino e il rinforzo dei boschi danneggiati dal fortunale dell’agosto 2023 nella Valle del Ticino, in connessione con la costruzione del Data Center di Bornasco.L’evento atmosferico aveva abbattuto gran parte degli alberi, con un impatto particolarmente grave sulle querce e sui pioppi, lasciando vaste aree esposte all’invasione di specie alloctone e alla perdita di biodiversità.

L’intervento prevede:

Ripristino attivo dei boschi, attraverso la piantagione di specie autoctone tipiche della valle (farnia, olmo, pioppo e acero campestre), fondamentali per il recupero della biodiversità vegetale e faunistica locale.

Rinfoltimento a cluster, mediante la messa a dimora di piccoli gruppi di piante per ettaro, per favorire la diversificazione ecologica e creare habitat differenziati per insetti, uccelli e piccoli mammiferi.

Gestione e manutenzione triennale, con attività di irrigazione, contenimento delle erbe infestanti e sostituzione delle piante non attecchite, al fine di garantire la sopravvivenza delle specie e il consolidamento della struttura forestale.

Selezione delle aree più vulnerabili, per un totale di circa 12 ettari distribuiti tra l’Isola dell’Ochetta e le sponde del Ramo dei Prati e della roggia Bredna, dove la rinnovazione naturale delle querce è quasi assente. Qui l’intervento contribuirà al recupero di habitat prioritari per la biodiversità.

L’obiettivo è ricreare boschi funzionali e resilienti, capaci di sostenere una ricca rete ecologica e di garantire nel lungo periodo la tutela della biodiversità della Valle del Ticino, contribuendo al tempo stesso agli obiettivi nazionali della Campagna Foresta Italia.
